Navigate to other release versions of Doxee Platform Composer

[6.6](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/composer-6-6)

[6.7](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/composer-6-7)

Tables are the most elaborate elements with the most settings in the Composer. They can be inserted into the document by drag&amp;drop from Palette Elements tab in the right panel.

Subsequently a dialog opens with which the following properties can be initialized:

- Rows

defines the number of rows the table should be created with.

- Columns

defines the number of columns with which the table should be created.

- Columns width

defines the width of the every table column. Each column width is the same at the beginning of table definition.

- Fit to parent

deactivates the Table width option (above) and uses the entire available page width. Columns are also in this case assigned equal widths.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Create table*

After input and confirmation of the desired table properties, the table is inserted at the current cursor location. The table is then editable and further properties can be defined if desired. Also, previous settings can be changed and further specified. In the following sections, further table configuration possibilities and working with tables will be examined more closely.

## Table properties
Tables provide a multitude of settings, most of which are reached in the right panel Styles tab &gt; Table and which can be configured at any time. As for all text parts, tables can be edited provided the corresponding document portion is editable.

### Setting column widths
Table column width can be set separately for each column by selecting respective column in editor via overlay and editing properties in right panel (Table Column section).

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Column width setting*

If some cells in the table have been split then new columns were created in the background automatically for these cells.

> Splitting of cells is not supported in current version of the Composer.

### Inserting rows
Tables may contain an unlimited number of rows and likewise be expanded at any time. To comfortably insert a new row at the end of a table, select the table to see table overlay and click on the plus icon at the bottom.

To insert another row in between two existing rows, hover the dots on the left side of table overlay and click the plus icons which appear on hover.

### Delete rows
To delete a row including all cells and their content, select the row via click in the left side of the overlay and then click the bin icon/button.

Keep in mind that when deleting a row you also delete all cells which originated from horizontal splitting of cells in this row.

### Insert columns
To insert additional columns into a table, select the table to see table overlay and click on the plus icon at the right side.

To insert another column in between two existing columns, hover the dots on the upper border of table overlay and click the plus icons which appear on hover.

### Delete columns
To delete an entire column including all cells and their content, select the column via click in the upper border of the overlay and then click the bin icon/button.

Bear in mind that when deleting a column, all cells originating from a horizontal splitting of cells in this column are also deleted

### Vertical Alignment
With vertical alignment the position of the text within a cell is controlled. You can set whether

the text is aligned above, in the middle, or at the bottom of the cell, as long as the cell height allows this. This is shown below.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Table cell alignment*

To configure the vertical cell alignment, select the chosen cell and set alignment in the right panel &gt; Table Cell section.

### Background color
The Composer provides several ways to define background color efficiently and flexibly from the right panel or floating toolbar or ctx menu.

- *Table background*

Sets the background color of the entire table.

Select the whole table via click on a circle in the upper left corner and configure background color in the right panel &gt; Table section.

- *Row &gt; Background*

Sets the background color of the entire table row.

Select the whole row via click on a table overlay and configure background color in the right panel &gt; Table section.

- *Cell &gt; Background*

Sets the background color of a single table cell.

Select the cell via click in the editor and configure background color in the right panel &gt; Table section.

> It might not be possible to select cell when it is fully filled with a block. This will be improved in a future version of the Composer.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Choosing a table background color*

In order to set the corresponding colors as uniquely as possible, the background colors for the respective areas are prioritized in the following order

- cell background

- row background

- table background

This means that when setting a cell background color on a cell, the color will always be used, regardless of whether a row or table background color was or is set beforehand or afterwards. Conversely, a row background color on a cell comes into play only when no cell background color has been set. Accordingly, the table background color gets set in cells and rows, only when these have nor received any color definition. Consequently you can assign any color to a single cell at any time.

To clear a color that has been set, open the corresponding color choosing dialog again, that is, for cell, row, or table background and use the *Clear *button (checker board button in the lower right corner). If this does not produce the desired effect, make sure that you removed the color from the proper element and repeat the procedure with the correct element.

### Border Settings
As with table colors, borders can be set both around the entire table, as well as rows or single cells. Select respective element and configure borders in the right panel &gt; Border section.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Border properties section*

This dialog consists of the following parts:

- Borders

Defines where the borders appear. Currently the following settings are available:

 ![](data:image/png;base64,) None  removes all borders

![](data:image/png;base64,)All  sets borders on all four sides

![](data:image/png;base64,) Set borders Top and Bottom

![](data:image/png;base64,) Set borders Left

![](data:image/png;base64,) Set borders Right

![](data:image/png;base64,) Set borders Top

![](data:image/png;base64,) Set borders Bottom

Because usually no border is set, it makes sense to first decide on this setting, since only in the Preview the other settings can be shown.

- Width

Allows the setting of a user defined border width in one of the units you can choose.

- Styles

Defines the border type to be set. Currently the following options are available:

no border  removes all borders

- solid

- dotted

- dashed

- double

- groove

- inset

- outset

- Color

Allows setting of a border color

- Preview

This always shows the appearance of the document with the current settings.

Changes are immediately applied.

### Table Header/Footer
The Composer allows you to define table header and footer lines. This is especially useful for long tables which span several pages, since the headers and footers are repeated on every page. To define the header or footer area, select one or both check-boxes in the right panel &gt;

Table section. Header/footer is automatically placed either at the table front or table end.

> It is NOT possible to use a table row as table header or table footer.

## Working with tables
Tables behave like any other text area in the document and can be enlarged, formatted, and edited. All available elements like page numbers or even tables can be inserted into a table. This section shows some cases how to define special layouts with tables.

### Navigating within tables
For moving through a tables columns left to right or top to bottom you can normally use up/down and left/right arrow keys.

### Tables as layout tools
Usually tables are used for data. Here we show how they can be used for complicated layouts. Tables are excellent for placing text contiguously and to give it uniform spacing. Here is an example how to use a part of your document to display person data:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Table with borders*

A table can be used with an appropriately designed column:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

*Table without borders*
